00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 contextCurrency.pl - Context for entering numbers with currency symbols and
00020 commas.
00021 
00022 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00023 
00024 This file implements a context in which students can enter currency
00025 values that include a currency symbol and commas every three digits.
00026 You can specify what the currency symbol is, as well as what gets
00027 used for commas and decimals.
00028 
00029 To use the context, put
00030 
00031     loadMacros("contextCurrency.pl");
00032 
00033 at the top of your problem file, and then issue the
00034 
00035     Context("Currency");
00036 
00037 command to select the context.  You can set the currency symbol
00038 and the comma or decimal values as in the following examples
00039 
00040     Context()->currency->set(symbol=>'#');
00041     Context()->currency->set(symbol=>'euro');          # accepts '12 euro'
00042     Context()->currency->set(comma=>'.',decimal=>','); # accepts '10.000,00'
00043 
00044 You can add additional symbols (in case you want to allow
00045 more than one way to write the currency).  For example:
00046 
00047     Context("Currency")->currency->addSymbol("dollars","dollar");
00048 
00049 would accept '$12,345.67' or '12.50 dollars' or '1 dollar' as
00050 acceptable values.  Note that if the symbol cantains any
00051 alphabetic characters, it is expected to come at the end of the
00052 number (as in the examples above) and if the symbol has only
00053 non-alphabetic characters, it comes before it.  You can change
00054 this as in these examples:
00055 
00056     Context()->currency->setSymbol(euro=>{associativity=>"left"});
00057     Context()->currency->setSymbol('#'=>{associativity=>"right"});
00058 
00059 You can remove a symbol as follows:
00060 
00061     Context()->currency->removeSymbol('dollar');
00062 
00063 To create a currency value, use
00064 
00065     $m = Currency(10.99);
00066 
00067 or
00068 
00069     $m1 = Compute('$10.99');
00070     $m2 = Compute('$10,000.00');
00071 
00072 and so on.  Be careful, however, that you do not put dollar signs
00073 inside double quotes, as this refers to variable substitution.
00074 For example,
00075 
00076     $m = Compute("$10.99");
00077 
00078 will most likely set $m to the Real value .99 rather than the
00079 monetary value of $10.99, since perl thinks $10 is the name of
00080 a variable, and will substitute that into the string before
00081 processing it.  Since that variable is most likely empty, the
00082 result will be the same as $m = Compute(".99");
00083 
00084 You can use monetary values within computations, as in
00085 
00086     $m1 = Compute('$10.00');
00087     $m2 = 3*$m1;  $m3 = $m2 + .5;
00088     $m4 = Compute('$10.00 + $2.59');
00089 
00090 so that $m2 will be $30.00, $m3 will be $30.50, and $m4 will
00091 be $12.59.  Students can perform computations within their
00092 answers unless you disable the operators and functions as well.
00093 
00094 The tolerance for this context is set initially to .005 and the
00095 tolType to 'absolute' so that monetary values will have to match
00096 to the nearest penny.  You can change that on a global basis
00097 using
00098 
00099     Context()->flags->set(tolerance=>.0001,tolType=>"relative");
00100 
00101 for example.  You can also change the tolerance on an individual
00102 currency value as follows:
00103 
00104     $m = Compute('$1,250,000.00')->with(tolerance=>.0001,tolType=>'relative');
00105 
00106 which would require students to be correct to three significant digits.
00107 
00108 The default tolerance of .005 works properly only if your original
00109 monetary values have no more than 2 decimal places.  If you were to do
00110 
00111     $m = Currency(34.125);
00112 
00113 for example, then $m would print as $34.12, but neither a student
00114 answer of $34.12 nor of $34.13 would be marked correct.  That is
00115 because neither of these are less than .5 away from the correct answer
00116 of $34.125.  If you create currency values that have more decimal
00117 places than the usual two, you may want to round or truncate them.
00118 Currency objects have two methods for accomplishing this: round() and
00119 truncate(), which produce rounded or truncated copies of the original
00120 Currency object:
00121 
00122     $m = Currency(34.127)->round;    # produces $34.13
00123     $m = Currency(34.127)->truncate; # produces $34.12
00124 
00125 By default, the answer checker for Currency values requires
00126 the student to enter the currency symbol, not just a real number.
00127 You can relax that condition by including the promoteReals=>1
00128 option to the cmp() method of the Currency value.  For example,
00129 
00130     ANS(Compute('$150')->cmp(promoteReals=>1));
00131 
00132 would allow the student to enter just 150 rather than $150.
00133 
00134 By default, the students may omit the commas, but you can
00135 force them to supply the commas using forceCommas=>1 in
00136 your cmp() call.
00137 
00138     ANS(Compute('$10,000.00')->cmp(forceCommas=>1));
00139 
00140 By default, students need not enter decimal digits, so could use
00141 $100 or $1,000. as valid entries.  You can require that the cents
00142 be provided using the forceDecimals=>1 flag.
00143 
00144     ANS(Compute('$10.95')->cmp(forceDecimals=>1));
00145 
00146 By default, if the monetary value includes decimals digits, it
00147 must have exactly two.  You can weaken this requirement to allow
00148 any number of decimals by using noExtraDecimals=>0.
00149 
00150     ANS(Compute('$10.23372')->cmp(noExtraDecimals=>0);
00151 
00152 If forceDecimals is set to 1 at the same time, then they must
00153 have 2 or more decimals, otherwise any number is OK.
00154 
00155 By default, currency values are always formatted to display using
00156 two decimal places, but you can request that if the decimals would be
00157 .00 then they should not be displayed.  This is controlled via the
00158 trimTrailingZeros context flag:
00159 
00160     Context()->flags->set(trimTrailingZeros=>1);
00161 
00162 It can also be set on an individual currency value:
00163 
00164     $m = Compute('$50')->with(trimtrailingZeros=>1);
00165 
00166 so that this $m will print as $50 rather than $50.00.
00167 
00168 =cut
00169

00173 sub _contextCurrency_init {Currency::Init()}

00175 package Currency;
00176 
00177 #
00178 #  Initialization creates a Currency context object
00179 #  and sets up a Currency() constructor.
00180 #
00181 sub Init {
00182   my $context = $main::context{Currency} = new Currency::Context();
00183   $context->{name} = "Currency";
00184 
00185   main::PG_restricted_eval('sub Currency {Value->Package("Currency")->new(@_)}');
00186 }
00187 
00188 #
00189 #  Quote characters that are special in regular expressions
00190 #
00191 sub quoteRE {
00192   my $s = shift;
00193   $s =~ s/([-\\^\$+*?.\[\](){}])/\\$1/g;
00194   return $s;
00195 }
00196 
00197 #
00198 #  Quote common TeX special characters, and put
00199 #  the result in {\rm ... } if there are alphabetic
00200 #  characters included.
00201 #
00202 sub quoteTeX {
00203   my $s = shift;
00204   my $isText = ($s =~ m/[a-z]/i);
00205   $s =~ s/\\/\\backslash /g;
00206   $s =~ s/([\#\$%^_&{} ])/\\$1/g;
00207   $s =~ s/([~\'])/{\\tt\\char\`\\$1}/g;
00208   $s =~ s/,/{,}/g;
00209   $s = "{\\rm $s}" if $isText;
00210   return $s;
00211 }
00212 
00213 ######################################################################
00214 ######################################################################
00215 #
00216 #  The Currency context has an extra "currency" data
00217 #  type (like flags, variables, etc.)
00218 #
00219 #  It also creates some patterns needed for handling
00220 #  currency values, and sets the Parser and Value
00221 #  hashes to activate the Currency objects.
00222 #
00223 #  The tolerance is set to .005 absolute so that
00224 #  answers must be correct to the penny.  You can
00225 #  change this in the context, or for individual
00226 #  currency values.
00227 #
00228 package Currency::Context;
00229 our @ISA = ('Parser::Context');
00230 
00231 sub new {
00232   my $self = shift; my $class = ref($self) || $self;
00233   my %data = (
00234     decimal => '.',
00235     comma => ',',
00236     symbol => "\$",
00237     associativity => "left",
00238     @_,
00239   );
00240   my $context = bless Parser::Context->getCopy("Numeric"), $class;
00241   $context->{_initialized} = 0;
00242   $context->{_currency} = new Currency::Context::currency($context,%data);
00243   my $symbol = $context->{currency}{symbol};
00244   my $associativity = $context->{currency}{associativity};
00245   my $string = ($symbol =~ m/[a-z]/i ? " $symbol " : $symbol);
00246   $context->{_currency}{symbol} = $symbol;
00247   $context->operators->remove($symbol) if $context->operators->get($symbol);
00248   $context->operators->add(
00249     $symbol => {precedence => 10, associativity => $associativity, type => "unary",
00250         string => ($main::displayMode eq 'TeX' ? Currency::quoteTeX($symbol) : $symbol),
00251                 TeX => Currency::quoteTeX($symbol), class => 'Currency::UOP::currency'},
00252   );
00253   $context->{parser}{Number} = "Currency::Number";
00254   $context->{value}{Currency} = "Currency::Currency";
00255   $context->flags->set(
00256     tolerance => .005,
00257     tolType => "absolute",
00258     promoteReals => 1,
00259     forceCommas => 0,
00260     forceDecimals => 0,
00261     noExtraDecimals => 1,
00262     trimTrailingZeros => 0,
00263   );
00264   $context->{_initialized} = 1;
00265   $context->update;
00266   $context->{error}{msg}{"Missing operand after '%s'"} = "There should be a number after '%s'";
00267   return $context;
00268 }
00269 
00270 sub currency {(shift)->{_currency}}   # access to currency data

00273 ##################################################
00274 #
00275 #  This is the context data for currency.
00276 #  A special pattern is maintained for the
00277 #  comma form of numbers (using the specified
00278 #  comma and decimal-place characters).
00279 #
00280 #  You specify the currency symbol via
00281 #
00282 #    Context()->currency->set(symbol=>'$');
00283 #    Context()->currency->set(comma=>',',decimal=>'.');
00284 #
00285 #  You can add extra symbols via
00286 #
00287 #    Context()->currency->addSymbol("dollar","dollars");
00288 #
00289 #  If the symbol contains alphabetic characters, it
00290 #  is made to be right-associative (i.e., comes after
00291 #  the number), otherwise it is left-associative (i.e.,
00292 #  before the number).  You can change that for a
00293 #  symbol using
00294 #
00295 #    Context()->currency->setSymbol("Euro"=>{associativity=>"left"});
00296 #
00297 #  Finally, an extra symbol can be removed with
00298 #
00299 #    Context()->currency-removeSymbol("dollar");
00300 #
00301 package Currency::Context::currency;
00302 our @ISA = ("Value::Context::Data");
00303 
00304 #
00305 #  Set up the initial data
00306 #
00307 sub init {
00308   my $self = shift;
00309   $self->{dataName} = 'currency';
00310   $self->{name} = 'currency';
00311   $self->{Name} = 'Currency';
00312   $self->{namePattern} = qr/[-\w_.]+/;
00313   $self->{numberPattern} = qr/\d{1,3}(?:,\d\d\d)+(?:\.\d*)?(?=\D|$)/;
00314   $self->{tokenType} = "num";
00315   $self->{precedence} = -12;
00316   $self->{patterns}{$self->{numberPattern}} = [$self->{precedence},$self->{tokenType}];
00317   $self->{extraSymbols} = [];
00318 }
00319 
00320 sub addToken {}       # no tokens are needed (only uses fixed pattern)
00321 sub removeToken {}
00322 
00323 #
00324 #  Do the usual set() method, but make sure patterns are
00325 #  updated, since the settings may affect the currency
00326 #  pattern.
00327 #
00328 sub set {
00329   my $self = shift;
00330   $self->SUPER::set(@_);
00331   $self->update;
00332 }
00333 
00334 #
00335 #  Create, set and remove extra currency symbols
00336 #
00337 sub addSymbol {
00338   my $self = shift; my $operators = $self->{context}->operators;
00339   my $def = $operators->get($self->{symbol});
00340   foreach my $symbol (@_) {
00341     my ($string,$associativity) = ($symbol =~ m/[a-z]/i ? (" $symbol ","right") : ($symbol,"left"));
00342     push @{$self->{extraSymbols}},$symbol;
00343     $operators->add(
00344       $symbol => {
00345         %{$def}, associativity => $associativity,
00346         string => ($main::displayMode eq 'TeX' ? Currency::quoteTeX($string) : $string),
00347     TeX => Currency::quoteTeX($string),
00348       }
00349     );
00350   }
00351 }
00352 sub setSymbol {(shift)->{context}->operators->set(@_)}
00353 sub removeSymbol {(shift)->{context}->operators->remove(@_)}
00354 
00355 #
00356 #  Update the currency patterns in case the characters have changed,
00357 #  and if the symbol has changed, remove the old operator(s) and
00358 #  create a new one for the given symbol.
00359 #
00360 sub update {
00361   my $self = shift;
00362   my $context = $self->{context};
00363   my $pattern = $context->{pattern};
00364   my $operators = $context->operators;
00365   my $data = $context->{$self->{dataName}};
00366   my ($symbol,$comma,$decimal) = (Currency::quoteRE($data->{symbol}),
00367                   Currency::quoteRE($data->{comma}),
00368                   Currency::quoteRE($data->{decimal}));
00369   delete $self->{patterns}{$self->{numberPattern}};
00370   $self->{numberPattern} = qr/\d{1,3}(?:$comma\d\d\d)+(?:$decimal\d*)?(?=\D|$)|\d{1,3}$decimal\d*/;
00371   $self->{patterns}{$self->{numberPattern}} = [$self->{precedence},$self->{tokenType}];
00372   $pattern->{currencyChars}   = qr/(?:$symbol|$comma)/;
00373   $pattern->{currencyDecimal} = qr/$decimal/;
00374   if ($self->{symbol} && $self->{symbol} ne $data->{symbol}) {
00375     $operators->redefine($data->{symbol},from=>$context,using=>$self->{symbol});
00376     $operators->remove($self->{symbol});
00377     foreach $symbol (@{$self->{extraSymbols}}) {$operators->remove($symbol) if $operators->get($symbol)}
00378     $self->{extraSymbols} = [];
00379   }
00380   my $string = ($data->{symbol} =~ m/[^a-z]/i ? $data->{symbol} : " $data->{symbol} ");
00381   $context->operators->set($data->{symbol}=>{
00382     associativity => $data->{associativity},
00383     string => ($main::displayMode eq 'TeX' ? Currency::quoteTeX($string) : $string),
00384     TeX => Currency::quoteTeX($string),
00385   });
00386   $context->update;
00387 }
00388 
00389 ######################################################################
00390 ######################################################################
00391 #
00392 #  When creating Number objects in the Parser, we need to remove the
00393 #  comma (and currency) characters and replace the decimal character
00394 #  with an actual decimal point.
00395 #
00396 package Currency::Number;
00397 our @ISA = ('Parser::Number');
00398 
00399 sub new {
00400   my $self = shift; my $equation = shift;
00401   my $context = $equation->{context};
00402   my $pattern = $context->{pattern};
00403   my $currency = $context->{currency};
00404   my $value = shift; my $value_string;
00405   if (ref($value) eq "") {
00406     $value_string = "$value";
00407     $value =~ s/$pattern->{currencyChars}//g;   # get rid of currency characters
00408     $value =~ s/$pattern->{currencyDecimal}/./; # convert decimal to .
00409   } elsif (Value::classMatch($value,"Currency")) {
00410     #
00411     #  Put it back into a Value object, but must unmark it
00412     #  as a Real temporarily to avoid an infinite loop.
00413     #
00414     $value->{isReal} = 0;
00415     $value = $self->Item("Value")->new($equation,[$value]);
00416     $value->{value}{isReal} = 1;
00417     return $value;
00418   }
00419   $self = $self->SUPER::new($equation,$value,@_);
00420   $self->{value_string} = $value_string if defined($value_string);
00421   return $self;
00422 }
00423 
00424 ##################################################
00425 #
00426 #  This class implements the currency symbol.
00427 #  It checks that its operand is a numeric constant
00428 #  in the correct format, and produces
00429 #  a Currency object when evaluated.
00430 #
00431 package Currency::UOP::currency;
00432 our @ISA = ('Parser::UOP');
00433 
00434 sub _check {
00435   my $self = shift;
00436   my $context = $self->context;
00437   my $decimal = $context->{pattern}{currencyDecimal};
00438   my $op = $self->{op}; my $value = $op->{value_string};
00439   $self->Error("'%s' can only be used with numeric constants",$self->{uop})
00440     unless $op->type eq 'Number' && $op->class eq 'Number';
00441   $self->{ref} = $op->{ref}; # highlight the number, not the operator
00442   $self->Error("You should have a '%s' every 3 digits",$context->{currency}{comma})
00443     if $context->flag("forceCommas") && $value =~ m/\d\d\d\d/;
00444   $self->Error("Monetary values must have exactly two decimal places")
00445    if $value && $value =~ m/$decimal\d/ && $value !~ m/$decimal\d\d$/ && $context->flag('noExtraDecimals');
00446   $self->Error("Monetary values require two decimal places",shift)
00447     if $context->flag("forceDecimals") && $value !~ m/$decimal\d\d$/;
00448   $self->{type} = {%{$op->typeRef}};
00449   $self->{isCurrency} = 1;
00450 }
00451 
00452 sub _eval {my $self = shift; Value->Package("Currency")->make($self->context,@_)}

00454 #
00455 #  Use the Currency MathObject to produce the output formats
00456 #
00457 sub string {(shift)->eval->string}
00458 sub TeX    {(shift)->eval->TeX}
00459 sub perl   {(shift)->eval->perl}

00462 ######################################################################
00463 ######################################################################
00464 #
00465 #  This is the MathObject class for currency objects.
00466 #  It is basically a Real(), but one that stringifies
00467 #  and texifies itself to include the currency symbol
00468 #  and commas every three digits.
00469 #
00470 package Currency::Currency;
00471 our @ISA = ('Value::Real');
00472 
00473 #
00474 #  We need to override the new() and make() methods
00475 #  so that the Currency object will be counted as
00476 #  a Value object.  If we aren't promoting Reals,
00477 #  produce an error message.
00478 #
00479 sub new {
00480   my $self = shift; my $class = ref($self) || $self;
00481   my $context = (Value::isContext($_[0]) ? shift : $self->context);
00482   my $x = shift;
00483   Value::Error("Can't convert %s to a monetary value",lc(Value::showClass($x)))
00484       if !$self->getFlag("promoteReals",1) && Value::isRealNumber($x) && !Value::classMatch($x,"Currency");
00485   $self = bless $self->SUPER::new($context,$x,@_), $class;
00486   $self->{isReal} = $self->{isValue} = $self->{isCurrency} = 1;
00487   return $self;
00488 }
00489 
00490 sub make {
00491   my $self = shift; my $class = ref($self) || $self;
00492   $self = bless $self->SUPER::make(@_), $class;
00493   $self->{isReal} = $self->{isValue} = $self->{isCurrency} = 1;
00494   return $self;
00495 }
00496 
00497 sub round {
00498   my $self = shift;
00499   my $s = ($self->value >= 0 ? "" : "-");
00500   return $self->make(($s.main::prfmt(CORE::abs($self->value),"%.2f")) + 0);
00501 }
00502 
00503 sub truncate {
00504   my $self = shift;
00505   my $n = $self->value; $n =~ s/(\.\d\d).*/$1/;
00506   return $self->make($n+0);
00507 }
00508 
00509 #
00510 #  Look up the currency symbols either from the object of the context
00511 #  and format the output as a currency value (use 2 decimals and
00512 #  insert commas every three digits).  Put the currency symbol
00513 #  on the correct end for the associativity and remove leading
00514 #  and trailing spaces.
00515 #
00516 sub format {
00517   my $self = shift; my $type = shift;
00518   my $currency = ($self->{currency} || $self->context->{currency});
00519   my ($symbol,$comma,$decimal) = ($currency->{symbol},$currency->{comma},$currency->{decimal});
00520   $symbol = $self->context->operators->get($symbol)->{$type} || $symbol;
00521   $comma = "{$comma}" if $type eq 'TeX';
00522   my $s = ($self->value >= 0 ? "" : "-");
00523   my $c = main::prfmt(CORE::abs($self->value),"%.2f");
00524   $c =~ s/\.00// if $self->getFlag('trimTrailingZeros');
00525   $c =~ s/\./$decimal/;
00526   while ($c =~ s/(\d)(\d\d\d(?:\D|$))/$1$comma$2/) {}
00527   $c = ($currency->{associativity} eq "right" ? $s.$c.$symbol : $s.$symbol.$c);
00528   $c =~ s/^\s+|\s+$//g;
00529   return $c;
00530 }
00531 
00532 sub string {(shift)->format("string")}
00533 sub TeX    {(shift)->format("TeX")}
00534

00537 #
00538 #  Override the class name to get better error messages
00539 #
00540 sub cmp_class {"a Monetary Value"}
00541 
00542 #
00543 #  Add promoteReals option to allow Reals with no dollars
00544 #
00545 sub cmp_defaults {(
00546   (shift)->SUPER::cmp_defaults,
00547   promoteReals => 0,
00548 )}
00549 
00550 sub typeMatch {
00551   my $self = shift; my $other = shift; my $ans = shift;
00552   return $self->SUPER::typeMatch($other,$ans,@_) if $self->getFlag("promoteReals");
00553   return Value::classMatch($other,'Currency');
00554 }
